ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to analyze historical sources, how to see changes in time, how to compare different scenarios that happen within history

Learned how to analyze primary sources and read a lot of secondary sources in a short period of time
Also learned how to analyze continuities and changes across time and location
Online archival research was also something I improved upon in this class
Of course, I also learned a lot about how race and disease co-produce each other throughout American history. A lot of insights were incredibly fascinating if not surprising

I learned so much about the ways in which race and disease intersect, an intersection that is actually significantly more complex and deep rooted in history than I originally imagined. I learned so much in this class!
How to use primary sources to develop a historical argument; how to critically think about historical beliefs about race in the context of disease treatment
general reading comprehension skills, and how to ask for help/advice (even though it wasn't always given)

This was my first HSHM course, and believe me when I say I gained a WEALTH of knowledge about minority health in the U.S. We covered several different time periods and different minority groups and their treatment in the U.S. If you want to be a doctor, I think the stuff we discuss in the class is SUPER important in today's world.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength - interesting readings, engaging questions, Abedin always came with energy compared to the rest of the class (lol) 
Weakness - would have appreciated her to force us to have a meeting with her in order to improve my writing, more small group discussion, more engagement during class would have been nice, different sources like images, podcasts, newspapers, things of that sort

Strengths: Solid syllabus and reading selections, thoughtful general feedback on argument in all papers
Weaknesses: Discussion was slow to move in class sometimes, could get a little confusing at times
I really enjoyed the readings for this class!

The readings were pretty good, but the weekly work requirements were the same every week: do readings, listen to classmate's short presentation, ask questions, talk in class. Nothing changed, so it was hard to become engaged. It seemed like as a class we never dived into the material beyond brief overviews and 1.5 hours worth of general dicussion. On our own, I am sure we had more engaging thoughts, but there was not enough space to share them.

The only weakness I can think of is sometimes the class would be kinda silent, so I would feel like I'd have to say something even if I didn't plan on it at the moment. However, that's not really a flaw of the class so not sure how it could be fixed.

Strengths: seminar discussion, I always enjoyed the class and seeing what other people had to say, and giving my thoughts on their thoughts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Success - reading responses, interesting to get my mind thinking about the articles 
Weakness - more drafts due in order to help with writing process, more peer review since we had none, more smaller group discussions, felt more tangible to have conversations with 3 other people rather than 10 other people
Zoom made the discussion even slower sometimes, it felt hard to be present in an online format
Monotonous class. It was two hours of screen time with the same format each week. Just sort of floated by even though I enjoyed the class materials.
NA--seminar discussion, so was pretty successful over Zoom.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes - pretty interesting content, especially as a pre-med, makes you wonder about solutions to these problems and if there are any
Yes, definitely recommend to anyone interested in pursuing medicine or scientific research!

Not particularly, the course materials are wonderful but the class structure combined with the professor made the overall course not every engaging or interesting.

It was fun to branch off when we had our individual essays, you got to focus and study something personally intellectually stimulating.
I would recommend this course to every premed at this school; if they can get in, definitely take!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
